title: How to Calculate Amount of Paint to Paint a Room

steps.headline: Grab a paper, pencil, and a measuring tape.
steps.description: To determine how much paint you’re going to need for your room, grab a measuring tape to measure your walls, windows, and doors. You’ll also need something to write your measurements down, so grab a pen or pencil and a sheet of paper so that you don’t lose track of your numbers. There are online calculators that you can use to calculate how much paint you need. Keep in mind, some online calculators make assumptions about your walls, the type of paint you’re using, and the amount of paint in a can. You can find one at http://www.bbc.co.uk/homes/diy/paintcalculator.shtml. Grab a calculator to make your measuring easy. Use a rigid, metal measuring tape. A cloth tape is going to be too hard to keep straight over longer distances.

steps.headline: Measure the height and length of each wall.
steps.description: Pick a wall to start with. Take your measuring tape and stretch it out so that the hook presses against one end of the wall. Pull the measuring tape out all the way to the opposite end and note the width. Measure the height of the wall the same way going up and down the corner of the wall. Repeat this process for each wall that you’re painting. Ignore crown molding or baseboards in your measurements. Write your measurements down on your paper.Tip: If you are painting the ceiling, don’t worry about subtracting the space for ceiling fans or lighting. They aren't taking up enough space to make much of a difference. If your walls are really long or your ceilings are really tall, enlist a friend to hold one end of the measuring tape in place. If you’re going to paint the ceiling, grab a ladder. Place it near a corner and climb the ladder carefully before extending your measuring tape. Alternatively, if the ceiling is flat, you can measure the length and width of the floor and multiply the numbers together.

steps.headline: Multiply your heights and lengths to get the square footage, then convert to inches.
steps.description: Take a wall’s length and multiply it by the same wall’s height. Write this number down in a separate column. Repeat this process for every single wall that you’re going to paint. Make sure that you covert your feet to inches or your meters to centimeters before multiplying them together. For example, if you have a wall that is 6.7 feet (2.0 m) long and 9.6 feet (2.9 m) tall, multiply 79 inches (200 cm) by 114 inches (290 cm) to get 9,006 square inches (58,100 cm).

steps.headline: Add all of your square footages together to find the total.
steps.description: Once you’ve multiplied all of your walls together, add them all together. Be sure to include every single wall that you’re planning on painting in your calculation. For example, if you have 3 walls that you’re painting and they measure 9,006 square inches (58,100 cm), 10,403 square inches (67,120 cm), and 600 square inches (3,900 cm), add the numbers together to get 20,009 square inches (129,090 cm). Don’t bother converting your inches or centimeters back into feet and meters. You’ll do this after you’ve made a few subtractions for your windows or doors.

steps.headline: Measure the length and width of your windows and doors.
steps.description: On a separate sheet of paper, list each door and window that you aren’t going to paint on separate rows. Use your measuring tape to calculate the length and width of each window and door. Write your measurements down for each door and window on the corresponding line on your paper.Tip:You can either measure each door and window pane from edge to edge, or include the trim and molding. If you don’t include the trim or molding in your calculations, you’ll have some extra paint to work with.

steps.headline: Multiply the lengths and widths for each door and window together.
steps.description: For each individual door and window, multiply the length and width together. Write these numbers down in a separate column. Use the same unit of measurement that you used to calculate the sizes of your walls. This is the exact same process that you used to measure your walls. Don’t forget to convert your feet to inches or your meters to centimeters.

steps.headline: Add the square footages together to get the sum total.
steps.description: Add each of the square footages together to get the total size of your windows and doors on the walls that you’re painting. Recount the total number of rows that you’re adding together and make sure that you’re not missing any of your doors or windows.

steps.headline: Subtract the total size of your windows and doors from the walls.
steps.description: Take the sum total of your doors and windows and subtract it from the square footage of all of your walls. For example, if the total square footage of your walls came out to be 20,009 square inches (129,090 cm) and your doors and windows totaled 5,280 inches (13,400 cm), subtract 5,280 square inches (34,100 cm) from 20,009 square inches (129,090 cm) to get 14,729 square inches (95,030 cm).

steps.headline: Convert your final number back to feet or meters to make things easy.
steps.description: Most cans of paint list their coverage area in square feet or meters, so make things easier on yourself by converting the inches or centimeters. For example, 14,729 inches (37,410 cm) would come out to 14,729 square inches (102.28 sq ft) or 37,411.66 square centimetres (3.741166 m). To convert inches to feet, divide the number of inches by twelve. To convert centimeters to meters, divide the number of centimeters by 100. Round any decimals or fractions up until you’ve got a whole number.

steps.headline: Read the labels on cans of paint carefully to see how much they cover.
steps.description: Many cans of paint list the number of square feet or meters that they cover on the label. This is mainly because certain styles of paint cover walls differently. If the paint can lists the number of square feet or meters that it covers, use that measurement to determine how many cans to buy instead of estimating.Tip: In terms of different types of paint, 1 gallon (3.8 L) of oil-based paint may cover 300 square feet (28 m), while the same amount of acrylic paint may cover 400 square feet (37 m). For example, if a 1 gallon (3.8 L) can reads that it covers 350 square feet (33 m), and your wall is 10,000 square feet (930 m), divide 10,000 square feet (930 m) by 350 square feet (33 m) to determine how many gallons (or liters) you need.

steps.headline: Get roughly 1 US gal (3.8 L) for every 400 sq ft (37 m) if your walls are smooth.
steps.description: If you have a new or refurbished home with smooth walls, your paint won’t have a hard time covering your drywall. Buy approximately 1 gallon (3.8 L) of paint for every 400 square feet (37 m) that you’re going to paint. This is a rough estimate. The texture of your walls, brand of paint, and the temperature of your room will all change the amount of paint you need to cover a wall. For example, if your sum total is 4,265 square feet (396.2 m) and your walls are even, divide 4,265 square feet (396.2 m) by 400 square feet (37 m) to get 10.66 gallons (40.4 L). Always round up when you have a decimal or fraction at the end of your measurement for the paint. If you need more than 4 gallons (15 L), buy in 5 US gal (19 L) increments. Paint suppliers typically offer a discount for buying 5 US gal (19 L) containers instead of smaller 1 gallon (3.8 L) cans.

steps.headline: Buy approximately 1 US gal (3.8 L) for every 250 sq ft (23 m) if your walls are rough.
steps.description: If you’re painting exposed brick, stucco, or older drywall, your paint is going to have a rougher time soaking into the texture of your walls. Buy roughly 1 gallon (3.8 L) for every 250 square feet (23 m) to play it safe. For example, if your sum total is 4,265 square feet (396.2 m) and your walls are kind of old, divide 4,265 square feet (396.2 m) by 250 square feet (23 m) to get 17.06 gallons (64.6 L).

steps.headline: Get twice as much paint if you’re covering a color or adding 2 coats.
steps.description: If you’re going to be painting some red or green walls white, you’re going to need a lot more paint to cover your walls. If you plan on painting multiple coats, double the square footage that you calculated and use that as your final measurement when it comes to figuring out how much paint you need to buy.
